json.text: Will you need a hanky for Wonder?
"You are not ugly, Auggie."
"You're just saying that because you're my mom."
Letâ€™s just say bringing one might be a good idea.
Based on the award-winning book, this moving drama tells the story of Auggie Pullman,
a young boy with a genetic facial difference.
"I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid."
There are tons of thoughtful and caring characters in this movie.

Auggie is brave and patient in the face of
huge challenges and perseveres in tough times.
"Why are you sitting here then?"
"Because I want some nice friends for a change."
"Me too."
Not surprisingly, there are some scenes of bullying and fighting at school, plus lots
of mean insults directed at Auggie.

"If I looked like him, I swear I'd put
a hood over my face."

That said, this is ultimately a story about
kindness and compassion, and delivers lessons
on appreciating people for who they are, not what they look like.
"If they stare, let them stare. You can't blend in when you were born to stand out."

Common Sense says Wonder is OK for kids 10
and up, and we give it our Common Sense seal.

For more age-appropriate media picks, visit
us at commonsense.org.
